# Introduction

* Adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) 15-29 continue to **face higher risk** of HIV, and have been identified as a **priority population** for prevention
* The UNAIDS Global AIDS Strategy **recommends differentiating services** for AGYW geographically based on individual risk behaviour
* We used a spatio-temporal model to estimate the proportion of AGYW in **four behavioural risk categories** $k = 1:4$ in 13 priority countries at a district level in the years 1999-2020

|$k$|Category                 | Risk ratio|
|:--|:------------------------|----------:|
|1  |Not sexually active      |          0|
|2  |One cohabiting partner   |          1|
|3  |Non-regular partner(s)   |       1.72|
|4  |Female sex workers (FSW) |         13|

# Methods

* We used 48 household surveys (AIS, BAIS, DHS, PHIA)
* For the categories $k \in \{1, 2, 3^{+}\}$ we used all the data to fit a survey-weighted multinomial logistic regression via the multinomial-Poisson transformation
\begin{align}
    &y_{itak}^\star \sim \text{xPoisson}(\kappa_{itak}), \\
    &\log(\kappa_{itak}) 
    = \underbrace{\theta_{ita}}_{\text{Observation (IID)}}
    + \underbrace{\beta_k}_{\text{Category (IID)}}
    + \underbrace{\alpha_{ak}}_{\text{Age (IID)}} \\
    &+ \underbrace{\zeta_{ck}}_{\text{Country (IID)}} 
    + \underbrace{\phi_{ik}}_{\text{Spatial (Besag)}} 
    + \underbrace{\gamma_{tk}}_{\text{Temporal (AR1)}}
\end{align}
where $p_{itak} = \text{softmax}(\kappa_{ita})_k$
* To differentiate $3^{+}$ we used the 13 surveys with a paid sex question to fit a survey-weighted logistic regression
\begin{align}
    &y_{ia4}^\star \sim \text{xBinomial} \left( y_{ia3} + y_{ia4}, p_{ia4} / (p_{ia3} + p_{ia4}) \right), \\
    &\text{logit}(p_{ia4} / (p_{ia3} + p_{ia4}))
    = \beta_0
    + \beta_\texttt{cfswever} x_c \\
    &+ \underbrace{\alpha_a}_{\text{Age (IID)}}
    + \underbrace{\zeta_c}_{\text{Country (IID)}}
    + \underbrace{\phi_i}_{\text{Spatial (Besag)}}
\end{align}
where $x_c$ is the proportion of men in each country who are clients of FSW [@hodgins2021cfsw]
* We align our estimates for FSW to the UNAIDS Key Populations Atlas at the national-level [@johnston2022deriving]
* Inference performed with integrated nested Laplace approximation [@rue2009approximate] via `R-INLA`

# Discussion

* Using a **modular approach** allowed integration of all relevant data
* **Spatio-temporal smoothing** overcame high variance from small sample sizes
* Individual behaviour is a **key determinant** of risk and providing prevention services on the basis of behavior would allow many more new infections to be reached, **especially among FSW**
* Geographic delineation: cohabiting more common in the east and non-regular partner(s) more common in the south
* Large numbers of 15-19 in Mozambique already cohabiting 

## Limitations

* No adjustment for **reporting bias**
* **Risk category definitions** could be disputed
* No assessment **practicalities or costs** of strategies

## Future work

* Inclusion of **more surveys** e.g. VACS
* Extension to **general population** of adults 15-49
